1094480058574692352.text: I am quite sure that I found the max number of books that can be in the "Save For Later" list on @amazon. Unless it's a visual bug, the max amount is 600. I keep adding stuff to the list but it doesn't change. The least recent books get taken off. I think I have a problem.

1092860182479155200.text: [16] TL;DR: Make time for solitude; it's a lot easier than you think.

1092860181384445952.text: [15] I'm also starting to realize that some of my "profound epiphanies" are actually things that are "simple" that I over complicate. Like sitting still.

1092860180147113987.text: [14] To just sit and do nothing helps me filter out my brain. Because if an idea or thought pops up over and over then clearly it's worth something to my subconscious. Those are things I end up writing down.

1092860178528198661.text: [13] If I wrote everything down that goes through my brain everyday and if anyone found it, I'd be taken to get help. I also would not get anything done because I would spend all time writing nonsense and not filtering.

1092860177378873349.text: [12] I find that when I just take the time at least once day to sit and do nothing, I am able to just flush away things that cloud my mind. I remember using an app once that uses the metaphor of a stream or river of thoughts. Some people also suggest writing everything down.

1092860176082878464.text: [11] Anyway, I find the ability to sit still and just be with yourself and underrated skill. I am starting to find it almost as important as sleep. Sleep clears out our brain and restores our body. The ability to just do nothing can actually help make our sleep better.

1092860174790995968.text: [10] We spend so much energy thinking about the thing we are thinking about and never actually getting around to do it. The fear of "getting it wrong" paralyzes us.

1092860173251764227.text: [9] Some of us will "wait until tomorrow" because we took so much energy just to figure out how to sit or walk. But hey, we figured it out... Until we find that new article with that new study with <insert successful person here> and we question our ability to sit and walk.

1092860171666231301.text: [8] I cut out all that noise and just sit on the floor. If I'm going on a walk, I just wander aimlessly. If we are spending all this time *thinking* and *preparing* how to sit or walk then we become fatigued before we sit or walk.

1092860170315751424.text: [7] Guided meditations from an app; the perfect music for the background; how to sit to achieve "maximum self awareness"; where the best are places to do it, etc

1092860169141264384.text: [6] I disconnect the internet; I turn off all my lights and just sit on the floor. Some people call it meditation. I've said multiple things in this thread that are "fads" in today's world. With fads come a bunch of noise of "how" to do something.

1092860168084307968.text: [5] Sometimes I go to hot yoga. It always felt like a time to be able have quiet and be able to speak to myself - my mind, my body. But I recently started to dedicate parts of my day to be simply alone with nothing but my mind and my body.

1092860166628933635.text: [4] There is so much external stimuli and I find myself reactionary to it. Interesting blog post? Instantly read it. New episode of one of favorite shows? Queue it up. Email? Must respond within the hour. Text? I might be an asshole for not responding within the day.

1092860165009932290.text: [3] In addition, having an internet connection also makes it hard to achieve solitude because I always want to be connected or engaged with something. I've always felt if I'm not reading something or coding something 24/7, I am wasting away.

1092860161369300992.text: [2] Of course, when I say solitude, people may think that it's impossible to achieve in NYC - that you need to be in some remote location or some forest in nature. If you have access to that, wonderful but you can achieve that solitude even in the hustle and bustle of NYC.

1092860158248656899.text: [1] I've only recently began to realize the power and art of solitude. Living in NYC makes it such that it always seems I have to be moving or going to meetings or whatever. But there is value in just being alone with yourself and doing a lot of self reflection.

1091454459195080704.text: Serendipity has a hand in innovation, creation, and discovery. One sure fire way to increase serendipity? Diversity; in thought, perspectives and people.

1091446382475595777.text: Oops, I said that "killed the penicillin" when I meant to say "the term". Apologies.

1090731988384927744.text: And now the skies became clearer again with a nice sunset.

1090711745151336448.text: [PS] I don't know how long coalescing the platforms will take. Since as far as I know, they don't share any related code, they will have to rip out entire portions of all 3 code bases so they make a common base for them.

1090711744299876368.text: [Fin] This is all about unrelenting growth. Growth that can lead to more eyes on the product and keeping those eyes on the product for as long as possible to keep driving targeted ads in which IG can facilitate.

1090711743117045760.text: [16] It can also use all this data from the coalescing of platforms to keep driving targeted ads which points to the @ProPublica piece on FB blocking ad transparency tools.

1090711742206918656.text: [15] I am also reminded about a piece from @stratechery where @benthompson talks about The @Snap Memo that had "fastest way to communicate" appearing 25 times. Highly suggest the read:https://bit.ly/2sXYCTC

1090711741279936513.text: [14] Working with different brands and influencers, FB can turn IG into a place where people never leave and where we can make our decisions to go to a restaurant, travel to a new place, buy new clothes all within that platform and we can message all our friends in the process.

1090711740525002753.text: [13] So, while coalescing the platforms is being described for its messaging purposes, it's just to help drive growth, which will help with their ad business. But also, with IG, that can look to coalesce "experiences."

1090711739551891457.text: [12] We live in age where "Instagram Influencer" is a job title. Here's a piece by @HubSpot that lists different influencers across multiple topics ranging from food to fashion that have tens of thousands to millions of followers:https://bit.ly/2Pt6mK9

1090711738687860736.text: [11] https://bit.ly/2E9I3wj  According to KeyBanc Capital, in Q3 of 2018, IG accounted for about 15% of FB's ad revenue. The article also says that it is expected to grow to about 30% in 2020 and will drive 70% of new revenue by 2020 as well.

1090711737979019264.text: [10] I don't have stats to back this up but I imagine a lot of people (including myself) use IG to see where to get their next meal or where to go for their next trip. I even started using it more than Yelp or Foursquare recently.

1090711736984973314.text: [9] https://bit.ly/2Glpi6C  According to @StatistaCharts, most IG users fall between the 18-34 demographic as of October 2018. You can also see from the chart that its 13-17 demographic is quite small. According to the earlier @TechCrunch piece, FB paid users btwn ages 13-35.

1090711736167157760.text: [8] Coalescing the platforms in combination with them blocking ads transparency tools and tracking app usage will help them directly compete with @apple's iMessage and @Google's messaging services. But I think there is a little more at play here, specifically with IG.

1090711735202430986.text: [7] I also believe it is no coincidence that it comes at a time when Facebook moves to block ad transparency tools: https://bit.ly/2G3NwUC  and it paying teens to install a VPN that spies on them:https://tcrn.ch/2WttatR

1090711734468427781.text: [8] Growth has slowed down for Facebook. https://bit.ly/2FYkE14 .    According to @verge, that in the third quarter earnings report of  2018, it was confirmed that the daily active users in US and CA has remained flat and European users have actually decreased.

1090711733705027586.text: [6] First off, let's talk about what coalescing these platforms can do for FB: It can increase the time the amount of time people spend it the platform. As a result of this, they can showcase to advertisers high user engagement.

1090711732941672448.text: [5] Culturally, the US is different from China so while I don't think FB will become a national ID system, it can turn into a full on marketplace through IG.

1090711732195082240.text: [4] You can do many things on WeChat as well such as pay your utilities, order a ride service, ordering food, etc. Here's a @qz article that shows what can be done and not done on WeChat:https://bit.ly/2BFitOu

1090711731368837123.text: [3] WeChat is becoming China's national ID system. Two years ago, it released a feature where people can obtain a digital copy of their ID on it. WeChat has strong ties with the Chinese government.

1090711730471215105.text: [2] Tencent's @WeChatApp success has had the world talking on if something like that will ever exist in the west. With the acquisition of WhatsApp, it seems like FB would like to try its hand in doing so but I think it will be a tad different.

1090711729389084672.text: [1] Brief history for some people. 1) FB acquired IG in 2012. 2) FB acquired WhatsApp in 2014. 3) FB acquired Onavo in 2014. 4) Both the WhatsApp and IG founders left in 2018 probably because of FB's increased encroaching into their respective platforms.

1090711728378298369.text:
The @facebook greatest hits just keep on coming. This specific thread is about their decision (that was revealed a few days ago but I think most of us saw coming) to coalesce their @messenger, @instagram, and @WhatsApp platforms for messaging. 

Thread Incoming in 3...2...1

1090683375302660098.text: [PS] I believe sometimes, what we feel with the Internet, is speed or convenience but not necessarily "progress". Of course, it does depend on what your idea/definition of progress is.

1090681770494840832.text: [Fin] We live in an age of increasing complexity and it's only going to get more complex. The Problem Solving Progress Bars might not be as far up as we think they are or even, they are far up but is increasingly hard to move up even a single percentage point.

1090681769710493697.text: [29] As I was saying, we are spoiled because of what the internet provides to us and we (rightfully so) expect things to just happen. As we move through this age, the new (and old) problems that are popping up are getting ever difficult to solve.

1090681768406142976.text: [28] The working idea of this chart is that, rather than growing exponentially or linearly relative to population growth, progress peaked at 1873. This idea is a thread within itself which I can expand on later but it's definitely something to think about.

1090681766338269185.text: [27] At the time of writing, he believed we are at a bit of a technological slowdown and cites and interesting chart from physicist Jonathan Huebner on page 19. I don't have the book handy so here's the chart he's referring to from @newscientist (left). https://bit.ly/2CR7u1L pic.twitter.com/n3xDkKYAzL

1090681765637902337.text: [26] We are almost spoiled in a way as we went through the Internet Age and the progress we experienced just in our lifetimes. However, an interesting take on this topic is from @tylercowen and his book The Great Stagnation.

1090681764866080769.text: [25] Of course, something serendipitous might happen tomorrow and then in the next 20 years, we have an AI ruling over us but these problems are extremely difficult to solve.

1090677296921538561.text: [24] Fear and loathing and shock and awe articles exist left and right about it. While, I agree the many fronts of these pieces, we might be overstating how close it actually is.

1090677296128802816.text: [23] So, let's bring this to something that doesn't exist yet; a true #ArtificialIntelligence . I think many people a misguided idea on what AI is. Today, it's just #machinelearning with an inordinate ability on pattern matching that data we feed it. It doesn't "think".

1090677295445090304.text: [22] We are working with the knowledge we do know up until that point which is a very very tiny subset relative to the vast amount of knowledge available and disproportionately smaller than what we don't know and haven't discovered yet.

1090677294237143040.text: [21] It will take longer to get from 75% to 80% than it did to get from 55% to 65%. How do we know if we get to 75%? We don't because we are working on incomplete information.

1090677293343821826.text: [20] Throwing a theoretical number out there, let's say the progress bar is at 75%. The working theory I have is that as you make more and more progress on something we have very little to no knowledge on, the harder it is to get that extra percent.

1090677292559491073.text: [19] It might not be ubiquitous for decades and will have constraints such as extreme weather conditions and will need some sort of user interaction.

1090677291338924032.text: [18] Take for example #AutonomousCars. They exist, they are being tested but according to @business, @Waymo CEO @johnkrafcik gave a "cautious outlook on the industry.https://bloom.bg/2Q0r8Rq

1090677290672029696.text: [17] But we already have the knowledge to build web apps. What about things we don't fully understand yet? There are a lot of new technologies that, while exist, exist on a smaller scale or a "beta" version.

1090677289996746754.text: [16] Ideas should be able to evolve so even if you follow the "release early and often" paradigm, then even though your progress bar is at 100%, when you start another release cycle, it goes back down until you release again.

1090677289191378944.text: [15] In the scope creep context, the progress bar reaches say 90% and then a new feature gets put into scope and then, depending how you want to look at it, the bar just stagnates at 90% or you were actually not at 90% but say 80%.

1090677288209969152.text: [14] Release early and often helps combat scope creep because it doesn't front load everything and the kitchen sink into a first release of a project.

1090677287392079872.text: [13] This can also help support ideas such as "scope creep" and "release early and often." Scope creep refers to the continuous and uncontrolled growth of a project scope which leads to long delays and possibly, the project never being released.

1090677286624481280.text: [12] If we hold all things equal, when a new #developer takes on said project, the progress bar probably moves slower than someone who has 10 years experience.

1090677286028873729.text: [11] Obviously, after the project is finished and hosted, there is still a lot more to be done but the initial release is out.

1090677285131304960.text: [10] The Problem Solving Progress Bar in terms of #webdevelopment is pretty much guaranteed. If you take on a project to create a website/webapp and launch it, you will reach 100%. The time in which it takes will differ among individuals and skill sets.

1090677284246355968.text: [9] As of today, we are closing in on 2 billion according to that same site https://bit.ly/1fBvBR6

1090677281566146561.text: [8] Back in 2014, @timberners_lee tweeted that we passed a billion websiteshttps://twitter.com/timberners_lee/status/511988109211627520 …

1090677280668639233.text: [7] The first website was put up in 1991. It was the @CERN site and was made by none other than @timberners_lee. https://bit.ly/2rNMWFg

1090677279947145216.text: [6] A lot of discoveries happen "by accident" or by serendipity. Now, the "Problem Solving Progress Bar" is the idea that as we get closer and closer to "finishing" a solution, it gets harder and harder to figure out that maybe we aren't as close as we think we are.

1090677279192240129.text: [5] Alexander Flemming was examining a set of petri dishes when he discovered one of the dishes had been contaminated by a mold but instead of ignoring it, he examined it and eventually discovered the mold was making the antibiotic that killed the penicillin.

1090677278219091968.text: [4] And then some serendipitous discovery happened and then, from that, we exponentially move up. This actually happened with the discovery of penicillin.

1090677277464121345.text: [3] There was this great piece I read about the state of technological/scientific change is almost like a set of uneven, curved stairs (I need to find it in my notes). The idea is that scientific progress has periods of "stagnation" where things are being iterated and worked on

1090677276432351232.text: [2] There are many laws that can describe scientific and technological progress today: Moore's Law, Wright's Law, Kurzweil's Law, etc. Here's a study that defines a couple and tries to test accuracy:https://bit.ly/2WDlXYm

1090677275350179842.text: [1] Note: Some of these Tweets are excerpts from text messages/call conversations with a friend a I like to discuss these things with. The idea is still very much a work in progress but I want to be able to share what I have so far.

1090677274570117120.text:
I've been toying around with this #idea called the "Problem Solving Progress Bar." (Name still being worked out) It would be great if someone that knows about what I am about to thread out can refer me to some awesome resources.

Thread Incoming in 3...2...1

1088521682275446784.text: [Fin] For a place like the US, I believe local adoption is the way to go but for a place like Japan, they can bypass credit cards and go straight for blockchain. The combination of these two takes can really start putting #cryptocurrency into mainstream light.

1088521383683018752.text: [24] While credit cards create a logjam in a place like the US, Japan can put more attention onto blockchain and thus the crypto community.

1088520997563711488.text: [23] While I understand that, philosophically, this seems "wrong" to the crypto community, the narrative is that Japan is trying to bypass credit cards and go straight for blockchain.

1088520581736210433.text: [22] Prime Minister Shinzo Abe says that he wants 40% of payments to be cashless by 2025. Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group is teaming up with Akami to build a blockchain based payment for the Olympics.

1088520108144803842.text: [21] https://bit.ly/2sDV1K6  Japan is starting a new initiative to ditch cash for cryptocurrency. In the next year, many foreign visitors that come from countries where credit cards reign supreme (see earlier in the thread) will go to Tokyo for the #olympics

1088519474188304384.text: [20] https://bit.ly/2Tcx7RH  Japan still does the bulk of their transactions using cash. In fact, it accounts for almost 80% percent of transactions.

1088518911522496513.text: [19] Sorry peeps. I'm not done but this part is shorter than the first. Here we go: The second take that I think we need to look at for #cryptocurrency adoption is Japan.

1088518153779458050.text: [18] Turning the crypto narrative into something like this or even having crypto be the driving force behind community-based involvement and support I believe would be a very successful venture for a place like NYC and places around the US.

1088517621023158275.text: [17] Final food for thought: Many trends these days such as the yoga, health (vegetarianism/veganism), urban gardening, local eats, etc start as small communities and then grow really wildly in places like NYC.

1088516464913670145.text: [16] https://bit.ly/2TeVBKa  According to @ValuePenguin, AMEX lags behind other credit cards in merchant acceptance both domestically and globally.

1088516147786514440.text:
[15] Before I end off this point and move to the other, here are some more stats about merchants and credit cards: https://nerd.me/293KmQO 
According to @NerdWallet "most credit card issuers make the bulk of their profits from interest, but American Express relies more on fees

1088514978632613890.text:
[14] 2. Try their hand at issuing their own credit card. https://cnb.cx/2PNSxSP 
According to @BainCapVC, 2/3rds of Amazon Prime members would be open to banking with Amazon.

1088514563031605248.text: [13] Another reason I think this would be more likely to happen at the local level and move up is that larger merchants don't have an incentive to use something like a #bitcoin because they would 1. Try their hand a their own "cryptocurrency"

1088513572735541248.text: [12] If we get something like a plug and play router that subs as a payment processor for merchants paired with a nice digital wallet for consumers and put them in a local coffeeshop, I believe it would spread like wildfire.

1088513019192266752.text: [11] Younger people in these areas are more willing to try new things and are also more "philosophically driven" in the sense that they really do try to support local businesses.

1088512136769351681.text: [10] I asked why and was told that if I was gonna use a credit card, they would need to charge an extra percentage to offset the cost. The problem is that consumers love these credit cards for their perks and don't see the strain these business models puts on local merchants.

1088511638033059840.text: [9] Many local businesses straight up just take cash or restrict certain credit cards (usually AMEX or Discover) because of fees. A personal anecdote: I went to a local cake designer to buy a birthday cake and the owner asked me to pay directly through Venmo.

1088511143918878721.text: [8] Because of this logjam of cards, #cryptocurrency adoption for something like everyday purchases or large purchases faces a steep hill to climb, which is why I look to something at the local level.

1088510644347916290.text: [7] https://bit.ly/2nFivMO  @TSYS_TSS breaks this down even further at the preferred type of payment at each type of store. Cash usage remains dwindling. They also interestingly point out that digital wallets have a hard time catching on most likely due to security concerns.

1088509788974170112.text: [6] https://bit.ly/2U9JY72  According to @StatistaCharts, the leading payment method in the US is personal credit card at 29.5%, @PayPal at 14.8%, and personal debit card at 9.2%.

1088508467202138112.text: [5] But the problem with this narrative (while correct) is that most people around here use their debit and credit cards mostly. Each comes with their own perks and rewards and we are fully entrenched in a credit card based society.

1088507792393207816.text: [4] People think (and rightfully so) that the UX needs to be such that the person using doesn't know they are actually using cryptocurrency. Most people don't really know how their credit cards work because it doesn't really matter. Swipe > Pay > Done.

1088507460556595200.text: [3] I live in #NYC, specifically #Brooklyn so the idea is to capture the attention of "hipsters" or the young crowd that hangs around places like #Williamsburg. These people are more willing to try different things especially if it's different and new.

1088507041142968320.text: [2] Lets start with a place like the US: Lets assume that the UX of #bitcoin and #lightningnetwork have been ironed out. I think #cryptocurrency adoption here will happen at the local level.

1088505994617995265.text: [1] Before I begin, I want to note that I think this is less of a winter and more of a "retooling" phase. Winter implies nothing is being done but I definitely don't think that's the case. I also want to reserve this for payment based systems not tokenized securities.

1088503665189707777.text:
https://bit.ly/2FVDFjN 

A really cool take on the #10YearChallenge. It shows how popular websites such as @Google, @amazon, @YouTube, @apple, @github, @StackOverflow, etc have changed over the years.

1088089513556168707.text: Fin/ I'd argue that if you are a programmer, then taking cues from other fields and people/perspectives is a must for your growth. The stuff we create will have an impact. What will be your impact?

1088089155962355713.text: 13/ We are at a time in history unlike any other. It's important to be inclusive, understanding, and reflective and explorative about ourselves of what we know and don't know.

1088088531363344385.text: 12/ It also shows the importance of diversity in all facets. If you're secluding yourself to your own siloed worldview and not learning or at least interacting with other perspectives, then the code your write will reflect that.

1088087890574434304.text: 11/ That's why it's always important to update your worldview outside your field, no matter how uncomfortable it may be. Programming should be a self reflective experience that you start discovering more things about yourself and the world.

1088087388382003201.text: 10/ It's like having a child that doesn't grow into reasoning for itself. It's just takes your data and iterates on it, biases included. As it learns, you're still feeding it inherent biases based on your experiences.

1088086488905146376.text: 9/ In your studies, you learned that you need to train your data. The quality of the data that these algorithms will use to learn from is a reflection of all your knowledge and mental models up until this very point in time.

1088086031394590721.text: 8/ Which leads us into algorithms, specifically machine learning based ones: You learned so much and have been studying machine learning and are ready for that new job.

1088085452882669569.text: 7/ So, if we are not updating our mental models outside of our respective fields, the decisions we make, the code we write, will be a reflection of each one of us at that very moment in time.

1088085139987595264.text: 6/ You see, every line of code we write is like a personal signature (no pun intended). It is a reflection of what we know and don't know and all of our biases (not just the ones in our fields) that we retain in everyday life.

1088084639183486976.text: 5/ So why am I telling this seemingly obvious story? Because we all have self serving biases and unseen biases baked into us. We are updating our mental models and reality in our respective fields but not always thinking about them in other facets of life.

1088084010276974592.text: 4/ After however long, you leave the company for new horizons but now this new company has other ways of doing things. So you learn it and excel at it. Your mental models keep growing and growing.

1088083610056429568.text: 3/ You're starting to solve bigger and bigger problems. You interview with someone and get a cool job. This company has a specific way of doing things so you learn how to do it their way.

1088083060938207232.text: 2/ But that's okay. You keep learning and struggling and you get better and better; each line of code becoming more eloquent and thoughtful over time. But as is the case in programming, you're always learning something new so you keep updating your mental models.

1088082604832817158.text: 1/ Let's start from the very beginning: You just started programming. You're making cool, small apps and you're having a lot of fun. But since you just started programming, your mental models are limited so the range of which you solve problems are also limited in scope.

1088081966489104384.text: Apparently, there is some kind of controversy on algorithms and biases. So, I'd like to dispell some of it in the upcoming thread.

1088075222954184704.text: Fin/ I'm sure other developers have more greatest hits to add but there's a rough list that resmebles, at least my experience up until this point of my career. I'm sure I'll add a lot more going forward.

1088074195693654022.text: 5/ "No, I don't know what this code does... Yes, I did write it", "I think you are overstating what <insert new technology here> does", "What do you mean I need to use @java?", and "I am just gonna quit and become a bartender"

1088071927510515712.text: 4/ "It takes a lot longer than you think to make that", "But it works on my machine...", "This is the best or worst 10 lines of code I've ever written because I didn't use @Google  to do write them", ... >

1088070564592476161.text: 3/ "No blockchain probably isn't for <insert ridiculous use case here>", "I just spent 9 hours debugging the same problem but I figured it out! *Screen shows nothing but a large blue dot*, "#vim or #emacs?", "#tabs or #spaces", ... >

1088069121248501761.text: 2/ "No, I did not test it", "No, I won't make this app for you", "@StackOverflow doesn't have an answer to my bug, I'm screwed",  "I have this billion dollar idea", "I spend more time praying than coding on release day", "I actually have no idea what I'm doing", ... >

1088067765833998336.text: 1/ Hi, I'm have a CS degree/am a dev. You may know me from my greatest hits including, "No, I cannot fix your laptop", "No, I cannot hack your enemies' @facebook accounts", "Dev is not only about creating apps", "What do you mean there's a new #javascript framework?",  ... >https://twitter.com/arjunblj/status/1087794973137870848 …
